Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: TWC: Collaborative: iPrivacy: Automatic Recommendation of Personalized Privacy Settings for Image Sharing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to investigate a comprehensive image privacy recommendation system, called iPrivacy (image Privacy), which can efficiently and automatically generate proper privacy settings for newly shared photos that also considers consensus of multiple parties appearing in the same photo. Photo sharing has become very popular with the growing ubiquity of smartphones and other mobile devices. However, many people especially young users of social networks often share private photos about themselves and their friends without being aware of the potential impact on their future lives caused by unwanted disclosure and privacy violations. Although some photo sharing platforms start to offering functions of privacy configuration, such manual process could be very tedious for users and also error-prone since not many users have sufficient background knowledge about privacy. This project will address these rising privacy concerns of photo sharing in social sites and benefit billions of social network users. The broader impact of this project will be further enhanced by the integration of education and research. A range of educational activities will be carried out including curriculum development, professional training for students and cybersecurity camp for K-12 teachers, with emphasis to under-represented groups.

This project will seamlessly integrate expertise from two different domains: image understanding and privacy management, leading to one of the first comprehensive and automatic policy recommendation systems. The proposed project contains the following innovative researches. First, a multi-party privacy-sensitive object identification algorithm will be developed which will be capable of automatically generating the identity of each human subject in a photo so as to automate the subsequent privacy harmonization process. Second, a unique privacy harmonization approach will be designed, which will conduct hierarchical privacy policy mining to understand different levels of privacy concerns in communities, recommend policies that effectively harmonize privacy preferences of multiple people appearing in the same photo and also adapt to the evolution of people's privacy preferences. The proposed iPrivacy system will not only fully release the burden of privacy configuration at users' side, but will also promote better privacy practice based on knowledge learned from large-scale historical and societal information.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the growing ubiquity of smartphones and other mobile devices, photo sharing has now become very popular. However, many people especially young users of social networks often share private photos about themselves and their friends without being aware of the potential impact on their future lives caused by unwanted disclosure and privacy violations. Although some photo sharing platforms start offering functions of privacy configuration, such manual process could be very tedious for users and also error-prone since not many users have sufficient background knowledge about privacy. Therefore, in this project, we designed a comprehensive image privacy recommendation system, called iPrivacy (image Privacy). The uniqueness of the project lies in the seamless integration of techniques on image processing, image understanding and privacy management. The developed iPrivacy system can efficiently create and enforce proper privacy settings for newly shared photos while considering various privacy preferences of multiple human subjects depicted in the same photo.

The iPrivacy system consists of the following five major components: (1) Deep CNN based semantic image segmentation and privacy-sensitive object detection which can accurately identify each individual human subject on the photo who has specified privacy concerns; (2) Hierarchical multi-party privacy policy recommendation that can automatically harmonize privacy preferences from different parties; (3) Image-tag based policy recommendation that resolves the system cold start problem whereby a new user may have very few images for the system to learn; (4) Privacy risk estimation and alert which predict  image sharing propagation, calculate the image disclosure probability to unwanted parties, and issue alerts to users; (5) Automatic privacy enforcement that applies image modification techniques such as face blurring based on privacy policies.

The proposed iPrivacy system addresses the rising privacy concerns of photo sharing in social sites and may benefit billions of social network users. The iPrivacy system will not only release the burden of privacy configuration at users' side, but will also be able to provide recommendations of better privacy practice based on knowledge learned from large-scale historical and societal information.The research findings from this project have led to total 7 publications, including 4 major security journals and 3 conference papers. One of the conference papers won the best paper award. 

In addition, the broader impact of this project has been further enhanced by the integration of education and research. A range of educational activities has been carried out such as the curriculum development and professional training for students. Specifically, two PhD students and two undergraduate REU students have been working on this project. One of the PhD students have graduated in May 2019. One of the undergraduates joined the PhD program in spring 2019. Two new female graduate students (1 PhD, 1 MS) just joined the research group and plan to continue the research on image privacy protection on social networks. The project team also conducted three years of summer security camps for K-12 teachers to reach out to broader communities.
